column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: An advanced type of substitution cipher that uses a simple polyalphabetic code.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Access control list (ACL): specifications of authorization that govern the rights and privileges of users to a particular information asset. ACLs include user access lists, matrices, and capabilities tables.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Access control matrix: an integration of access control lists (focusing on assets) and capability tables (focusing on users) that results in a matrix with organizational assets listed in the column headings and users listed in the row headings.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Adverse event: an event with negative consequences that could threaten the organization’s information assets or operations.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: After-action review: a detailed examination of the events that occurred from first detection to final recovery.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Alert message: a scripted description of the incident that usually contains just enough information so that each person knows what portion of the IR plan to implement without slowing down the notification process.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Alert roster: a document that contains contact information for people to be notified in the event of an incident.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Business continuity plan (BC plan): the documented product of business continuity planning; a plan that shows the organization’s intended efforts if a disaster renders the organization’s primary site are not feasible.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Business continuity planning (BCP): The actions taken by senior management to develop and implement the BC policy, plan, and continuity teams.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Business resumption planning (BRP): The actions taken by senior management to develop and implement a combined DR and BC policy, plan, and set of recovery teams.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Business impact analysis (BIA): An investigation and assessment of the various adverse events that can affect the organization, conducted as a preliminary phase of the contingency planning process, which includes a determination of how critical a system or set of information is to the organization’s core processes and recovery priorities.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Capabilities table: A lattice-based access control with rows of attributes associated with a particular subject (such as a user).

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Cold site: A facility that provides only rudimentary services, with no computer hardware or peripherals. Cold sites are used for BC operations.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Computer forensics: the process of collecting, analyzing, and preserving computer-related evidence.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Configuration rules: the instructions a system administrator codes into a server, networking device, or security device to specify how it operates.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Contingency plan: the documented product of contingency planning; a plan that shows the organization’s intended efforts in reaction to adverse events.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Contingency planning (CP): The actions taken by senior management to specify the organization’s efforts and actions if an adverse event becomes an incident or disaster. This planning includes incident response, disaster recovery, and business continuity efforts, as well as preparatory business impact analysis.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Contingency planning management team (CPMT): The group of senior managers and project members organized to conduct and lead all CP efforts.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Corporate governance: executive management’s responsibility to provide strategic direction, ensure the accomplishment of objectives, oversee that risks are appropriately managed, and validate responsible resource use.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Crisis management: An organization’s set of planning and preparation efforts for dealing with potential human injury, emotional trauma, or loss of life as a result of a disaster.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Database shadowing: A backup strategy to store duplicate online transaction data along with duplicate databases at the remote site on a redundant server. This server combines electronic vaulting with remote journaling by writing multiple copies of the database simultaneously to two locations.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: De facto standard: a standard that has been widely adopted or accepted by a public group rather than a formal standards organization.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: De jure standard: a standard that has been formally evaluated, approved, and ratified by a formal standards organization.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Defense in depth: a strategy for the protection of information assets that uses multiple layers and different types of controls (managerial, operational, and technical) to provide optimal protection.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Disaster: an adverse event that could threaten the viability of the entire organization. A disaster may either escalate from an incident or be initially classified as a disaster.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Disaster recovery plan (DR plan): the documented product of disaster recovery planning; a plan that shows the organization’s intended efforts in the event of a disaster.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Disaster recovery planning (DRP): The actions taken by senior management to specify the organization’s efforts in preparation for and recovery from a disaster.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Electronic vaulting: A backup method that uses bulk batch transfer of data to an off-site facility; this transfer is usually conducted via leased lines or secure Internet connections.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Enterprise information security policy (EISP): The high-level information security policy that sets the strategic direction, scope, and tone for all of an organization’s security efforts.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Evidence: a physical object or documented information that proves an action occurred or identifies the intent of a perpetrator.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Goals: sometimes used synonymously with objectives; the desired end of a planning cycle.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Governance: “The set of responsibilities and practices exercised by the board and executive management with the goal of providing strategic direction, ensuring that objectives are achieved, ascertaining that risks are managed appropriately and verifying that the enterprise’s resources are used responsibly.”

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Guidelines: Nonmandatory recommendations the employee may use as a reference in complying with a policy. If the policy states to “use strong passwords, frequently changed,” the guidelines might advise that “we recommend you don’t use family or pet names, or parts of your Social Security number, employee number, or phone number in your password.”

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Hierarchical roster: an alert roster in which the first person calls a few other people on the roster, who in turn call others. This method typically uses the organizational chart as a structure.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Hot site: A fully configured computing facility that includes all services, communications links, and physical plant operations. Hot sites are used for BC operations.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Incident: an adverse event that could result in loss of an information asset or assets, but does not currently threaten the viability of the entire organization.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Incident candidate: see adverse event.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Incident classification: the process of examining an incident candidate and determining whether it constitutes an actual incident.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Incident damage assessment: the rapid determination of how seriously a breach of confidentiality, integrity, and availability affected information and information assets during an incident or just following one.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Incident response plan (IR plan): the documented product of incident response planning; a plan that shows the organization’s intended efforts in the event of an incident.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Incident response planning (IRP): the actions taken by senior management to specify the organization’s processes and procedures to anticipate, detect, and mitigate the effects of an incident.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Information security blueprint: In information security, a framework or security model customized to an organization, including implementation details.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Information security framework: In information security, a specification of a model to be followed during the design, selection, and initial and ongoing implementation of all subsequent security controls, including information security policies, security education and training programs, and technological controls. Also known as a security model.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Information security governance: the application of the principles of corporate governance to the information security function.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Information security model: See information security framework.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Information security policy: a set of rules that protects an organization’s information assets.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Issue-specific security policy (ISSP): An organizational policy that provides detailed, targeted guidance to instruct all members of the organization in the use of a resource, such as one of its processes or technologies.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Managerial guidance SysSP: A systems-specific security policy that expresses management’s intent for the acquisition, implementation, configuration, and management of a particular technology, written from a business perspective.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Managerial controls: information security safeguards that focus on administrative planning, organizing, leading, and controlling, and that are designed by strategic planners and implemented by the organization’s security administration. These safeguards include governance and risk management.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Maximum tolerable downtime (MTD): The total amount of time the system owner or authorizing official is willing to accept for a mission/business process outage or disruption, including all impact considerations

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Mutual agreement: a continuity strategy in which two organizations sign a contract to assist the other in a disaster by providing BC facilities, resources, and services until the organization in need can recover from the disaster.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Objectives: sometimes used synonymously with goals; the intermediate states obtained to achieve progress toward a goal or goals.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Operational plan: the documented product of operational planning; a plan for theorganization’s intended operational efforts on a day-to-day basis for the next several months.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Operational controls: information security safeguards focusing on lower-level planning that deals with the functionality of the organization’s security. These safeguards include disaster recovery and incident response planning.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Operational planning: the actions taken by management to specify the short-term goals and objectives of the organization in order to obtain specified tactical goals, followed by estimates and schedules for the allocation of resources necessary to achieve those goals and objectives.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Policy administrator: an employee responsible for the creation, revision, distribution, and storage of a policy in an organization.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Practices: Examples of actions that illustrate compliance with policies. If the policy states to “use strong passwords, frequently changed,” the practices might advise that “according to X, most organizations require employees to change passwords at least semi-annually.”

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Procedures: Step-by-step instructions designed to assist employees in following policies, standards, and guidelines.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Recovery point objective (RPO): The point in time prior to a disruption or system outage to which mission/business process data can be recovered after an outage (given the most recent backup copy of the data).

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Recovery time objective (RTO): The maximum amount of time that a system resource can remain unavailable before there is an unacceptable impact on other system resources, supported mission/business processes, and the MTD.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Redundancy: The use of multiple types and instances of technology that prevent the failure of one system from compromising the security of information.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Remote journaling: The backup of data to an off-site facility in close to real time based on transactions as they occur.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Security domain: an area of trust within which information assets share the same level of protection. Each trusted network within an organization is a security domain. Communication between security domains requires evaluation of communications traffic.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Security education, training, and awareness (SETA): a managerial program designed to improve the security of information assets by providing targeted knowledge, skills, and guidance for an organization’s employees.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Security perimeter: The boundary in the network within which an organization attempts to maintain security controls for securing information from threats from untrusted network areas.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Sequential roster: an alert roster in which a single contact person calls each person on the roster.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Service bureau: A continuity strategy in which an organization contracts with a service agency to provide a BC facility for a fee.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Standard: A detailed statement of what must be done to comply with policy, sometimes viewed as the rules governing policy compliance.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Strategic plan: the documented product of strategic planning; a plan for the organization’s intended strategic efforts over the next several years.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Strategic planning: the process of defining and specifying the long-term direction to be taken by an organization, and the allocation and acquisition of resources needed to pursue this.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Sunset clause: a component of policy or law that defines an expected end date for its applicability.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Systems-specific security policies (SysSPs): Organizational policies that often function as standards or procedures to be used when configuring or maintaining systems.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Tactical plan: the documented product of tactical planning; a plan for the organization’s intended tactical efforts over the next few years.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Tactical planning: the actions taken by management to specify the intermediate goals and objectives of the organization in order to obtain specified strategic goals, followed by estimates and schedules for the allocation of resources necessary to achieve those goals and objectives.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Technical controls: information security safeguards that focus on the application of modern technologies, systems, and processes to protect information assets. These safeguards include firewalls, virtual private networks, and IDPSs.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Technical specifications SysSP: A systems-specific security policy that expresses technical details for the acquisition, implementation, configuration, and management of a particular technology, written from a technical perspective.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Time-share: A continuity strategy in which an organization co-leases facilities with a business partner or sister organization. A time-share allows the organization to have a BC option while reducing its overall costs.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Warm site: a facility that provides many of the same services and options as a hot site, but typically without installed and configured software applications. Warm sites are used for BC operations.

column7: Principles of Information Security, 6th Edition. Cengage. ISBN10: 1-337-10206-7; ISBN13: 978-1-337-10206-3.
column8: Work recovery time (WRT): The amount of effort (expressed as elapsed time) necessary to make the business function operational after the technology element is recovered (as identified with RTO). Tasks include testing and validation of the system.

column8: A tendency to err in a particular direction.  Example: a weather forecaster who generally predicts the temperature to be hotter than it typically is.

column8: A strong, preconceived notion we have of someone or something based on inforrmation we have, perceive to have (but may lack).  These preconcieved notions are mental short-cuts which the human brain produces to exepedite processing information and making decisions.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: A cognitive bias in which a positive impression of a person in one area of expertise results in a positive view of that person in other, unrelated areas of expertise.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: A cognitive bias in which the way in which information is presented influences the way the receiver of that information makes decisions using the information.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: The tendency to believe that the way things are presently will persist into the future.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Increasing accuracy costs time.  Saving time costs accuracy.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Asking whether the outcome of a decision, whether good or bad, will likely have a significant impact on an individual's, group's, or organization's general level of happiness.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: When the same type of decision comes up over and over again and there are repeated opportunites to choose options, including options which may have been rejected in the past -- an excellent learning environment.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Asking "if this were the only option would we choose it and be happy?"

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Investing time and effort in rank sorting options so that time may be saved in the final decision making as the top options on the list will include the best choice and there are likely to be less significant differences between the best choice and it's peers at the top of the list or 'menu'.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: When an option is decided upon or chosen, the potential benefits of the options not chosen are lost and considered the cost of a missed opportunity.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Finding ways to make low-impact, easy-to-quit decisions in advance of a high-impact, harder-to-quit decision in order to build more accurate models of the world.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: The tendency to believe that an event, after it has occurred, was predictable or inevitavle.  Also referred to as "knew-it-all-along" thinking or "creeping determinism".

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Equating the quality of a decision with the quality of it's outcome.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: When facts learned after a decision or event 'creep' into recollection of facts which were known before the decision was made.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: When a bad outcome creates an emotionally hot state which compromises the quality of decision making.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Projecting into a future perspective to consider the decision making process which led to success or failure at achieving a goal.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Decision making motivated by the desire to make the optimal decision which results in examning every possible option and the nuances of each option in an attempt to make a perfect decision -- also referred to as 'analysis paralysis".

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Decision making motivated by choosing the first satisfying option available.

column7: "Effective Decision Making"  Eugene Davydov.  29-Jun-2021.  CST2410-OL20-Su21.
column8: Envisioning the obstacle which may stand in the way of achieving the desired goals and confronting those obstacles.
